item.title: News Media Scrambles to Cover Paris Shootings
item.description: American media outlets rushed reporters to Paris, while networks shifted their programming in the wake of the killings.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN

item.title: ISIS Leader in Libya Is Targeted in U.S. Airstrike
item.description: The United States has broadened its fight against the Islamic State, targeting the group’s senior leader in Libya on Friday night, the Pentagon announced on Saturday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Egyptian Leaders Blame a Familiar Foe, Conspiracy, but Citizens Are Dubious
item.description: Faced with skepticism after a Russian plane crash in Sinai and flooding in Alexandria, Egyptian officials portray Western alarms of terrorism as a plot against Egypt.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Uncredited/Russian Ministry for Emergency Situations, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Egyptian soldiers collected victims’ belongings after a Russian jet crashed on Oct. 31 in Sinai.

item.title: Paris Attacks Were an ‘Act of War’ by ISIS, Hollande Says
item.description: President François Hollande called the attacks that killed 129 people in Paris an “act of war,” and he blamed the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER, AURELIEN BREEDEN and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Israeli Forces Destroy Family Homes of 4 Palestinians Accused in Shootings
item.description: The demolitions on Saturday were the most sweeping use of a recently revived, controversial antiterrorism measure since unrest escalated last month.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: As Paris Attacks Unfolded, Players and Fans at Soccer Stadium Remained Unaware
item.description: Coaches for France and Germany decided not to tell their players of the carnage, and most fans in the Stade de France just north of Paris had no cellphone reception.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Fans remained inside the Stade de France after the soccer game between France and Germany amid confusion caused by the attacks in the area.

item.title: Paris Attacks: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.description: A briefing with the latest information.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA SHANNON
item.media:description: The French government declared a state of emergency, tightened border controls and mobilized 1,500 soldiers following attacks in Paris on Friday night.

item.title: As Paris Attacks Unfolded, Players and Fans at Soccer Stadium Remained Unaware
item.description: Coaches for France and Germany decided not to tell their players of the carnage, and most fans in the Stade de France just north of Paris had no cellphone reception.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN

item.title: Tens of Thousands March in Seoul, Calling for Ouster of President
item.description: South Korean police fired water cannons and tear gas at protesters, who were brought together by a host of grievances, including President Park Geun-hye’s decision to replace school history textbooks.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: France Attacks to Dominate Agenda at G-20 Conference in Turkey
item.description: As President Obama heads to Turkey, an annual gathering of presidents and prime ministers is poised to become an urgent summit meeting on confronting extremism.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: In an address at the White House on Friday, President Obama called the situation in Paris an “attack on all of humanity” and an “outrageous attempt to terrorize innocent civilians.”

item.title: News Analysis: Paris Terror Attacks May Prompt More Aggressive U.S. Strategy on ISIS
item.description: With lethal strikes against Russia, in Lebanon, and now in Paris, the Islamic State shows its chilling reach, and becomes a broader threat.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Police forensic experts studied the scene of one of the seemingly synchronized attacks that unfolded across the Paris area on Friday. ISIS has claimed responsibility for these and other recent attacks.

item.title: Attacks in Paris Add Urgency to Talks on Ending Syria War
item.description: Top diplomats from more than a dozen countries met to discuss how to end the crisis in Syria, vowing to redouble their efforts to confront terrorism.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: CBS Shifts Emphasis of Democratic Debate to Reflect Paris Attacks
item.description: The network’s news team has reworked plans and reformulated questions for the Saturday debate to make them more related to terrorism and national security.
item.dc:creator: EMILY STEEL

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility, Calling Paris Attacks ‘First of the Storm’
item.description: The statement was issued online in Arabic, French and English and distributed via supporters on Twitter, according to a group that tracks jihadist propaganda.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Eagles of Death Metal, a Band Known for Wit, Now Mired in Tragedy
item.description: The band whose concert was the site of the worst violence in Paris is a blues-rock outfit with an irreverent side; all its members were reported safe.
item.category: Queens of the Stone Age (Music Group)
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.media:description: From left, Dave Catching, Jesse Hughes, Josh Homme and Matt McJunkins of Eagles of Death Metal performing at the Teragram Ballroom in Los Angeles last month.

item.title: Paris Attacks Kill More Than 100, Police Say; Border Controls Tightened
item.description: The Paris area reeled Friday night from a shooting rampage, explosions and mass hostage-taking that President François Hollande called an unprecedented terrorist attack on France.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man wounded at the Stade de France, where a soccer game had been in progress.

item.title: ‘Scene of Carnage’ Inside Sold-Out Paris Concert Hall
item.description: People attending a show by an American group, Eagles of Death Metal, described sudden terror when gunmen burst into the Bataclan concert hall.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Court Orders Arrest of Opposition Leader
item.description: The leader, Sam Rainsy, was ordered held in connection with a seven-year-old defamation case.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Hague Court Frees Congolese War Criminal
item.description: The International Criminal Court granted early release to Germain Katanga, a convicted war criminal from the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Suicide Bomb and Road Blast Kill 26 in Baghdad
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks that targeted Shiites.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
